snippet: In the final days before filing for bankruptcy protection, officials at New York City Opera learned that the 70-year-old company had lost the confidence of the donors it needed to survive.
abstract: Interviews with company officials, board members and donors of now-shuttered New York City Opera reveal that behind its optimistic facade the troupe had long been in even more precarious financial shape than it had publicly acknowledged; officials report that they had learned, in last days before City Opera filed for bankruptcy protection, that the company had lost confidence of the donors it needed to survive.

byline.original: By MICHAEL COOPER and ROBIN POGREBIN

lead_paragraph: In the final days before filing for bankruptcy protection, officials at New York City Opera learned that the 70-year-old company had lost the confidence of the donors it needed to survive.

headline.main: The Frenzied Last-Act Effort to Save City Opera
